header.title: Trans woman spat at by man telling her ‘You’re not really a woman’
header.postText: A trans woman was spat at and abused outside her place of work by a man ‘hanging around’ despite police being called.', 'It comes as police recorded at 81% rise in the number of hate crimes reported.', 'Natasha, a policy and engagement officer with trans youth charity Mermaids, says she was spat on and abused outside a a former workplace, while with a vulnerable service user in Leeds.', '‘Last year I was assaulted,’ she told Metro.co.uk. ‘A guy came up and started shouting. He started spitting on me quite a few times. I called police saying, “There is this guy hanging around outside our building, this is an emergency.” He was still in my face, shouting at me. When he realised I was on the phone to police, he walked away.’', 'Police didn’t respond, however, and the man returned around half an hour later.', '‘He was saying, “You are not really a woman” and all that stuff,’ Natasha said. ‘I called police again and said, “This guy is back. It would be really good if somebody could come out.”‘', 'She says she was just told to come into a station and give a statement, but the man couldn’t be tracked down so it was not taken further.', '‘This is not how you go about dealing with transphobic hate crime,’ Natasha said. ‘We should have equal protection under the Equality Act.’', 'She said the incident was ‘very upsetting’ and left her feeling police didn’t take transphobia seriously – although she says since then, officers in West Yorkshire Police have been given training in how to deal better with reports of this nature.', 'New data showed that in the last year, 1,944 transphobic hate crimes crimes were recorded across England, Scotland and Wales, compared to 1,073 incidents between 2016 to 2017.', 'Some 44 constabularies from around the country were asked to disclose the number of incidents that were registered in each police force. Eight did not provide full substantial data for the BBC investigation.', 'Owl, a non-binary trans rights campaigner and columnist for Metro.co.uk, said: ‘I’m not at all surprised at this, and it reflects my own experiences and the experiences of trans people around me.', '‘Hostility towards trans people has been on the rise in the UK, and has been facilitated largely by the media. There are countless articles, headlines and news pieces that paint trans people as dangerous and vilify us constantly.', '‘The current climate is very much like it was back when Section 28 was enacted, and it’s worrying that the media isn’t being more critical of the type of opinions they platform. Trans people are afraid to leave their homes and participate in society fully, as they face discrimination and even hate crimes at all avenues.', '‘The UK has a serious problem when it comes down to responsible and ethical reporting and minority issues, and groups such as trans people are being affected disproportionally. I hope that news like this will serve as a wake-up call and more people start protesting against this treatment, as hate crimes and violence will only continue to increase if we continue down this road we’re on.’', 'Lee Clatworthy, vice chair of Sparkle, the National Transgender Charity said: ‘The most worrying aspect of this massive increase in recorded transphobic hate crime is that we know that many more incidents go unreported, either because of a lack of trust in the police force, or because many trans people see verbal abuse or the threat of physical violence as a part of everyday life.', '‘The link between this increase in transphobic hate crime and the hostile environment surrounding gender diversity furthered by certain news outlets and on social media can also no longer be ignored.”
